description: Functions of several variables, vector-valued functions, partial derivatives and applications, double and triple integrals, conic sections, polar coordinates, vectors and analytic geometry, first and second order ordinary differential equations. Applications to physical sciences. Use of symbolic manipulation and graphics software in calculus.
name: CALCULUS II

values.comments:
The second course in a four-part calculus sequence, Math 114 covers multivariable calculus, partial derivatives, first and second order differential equations, vectors, and analytic geometry, with a focus on applications to the physical sciences.

Catering to students pursuing study in the natural sciences, engineering and economics, Math 114 prepares students for more advanced calculus, whereas Math 115 delves more into probability and matrices for students in the biological and health sciences. Math 114 fulfills the formal reasoning requirement for the College. This course works with the textbook “Calculus,” by Stewart.

Professor Zywina received very positive feedback from his students. Many praised his organizational skills; Professor Zywina outlined the overall course from the very first day “so students can see how everything builds,” and provided brief summaries of the previous lecture at the beginning of each class. He was accessible to his students and “always [had] his students\' best interest in mind.” Many students were also happy with the pace of the course, which ensured that students felt “comfortable with all of the course material,” and remarked that Professor Zywina\'s teaching style was “simple and straightforward.” In addition, many students liked his personality, commenting that “he makes jokes and is so friendly” and “tries to make the class as fun and entertaining as possible.”

The second course in a four-part calculus sequence, Math 114 covers multivariable calculus, partial derivatives, first and second order differential equations, vectors, and analytic geometry, with a focus on applications to the physical sciences.

Catering to students pursuing study in the natural sciences, engineering and economics, Math 114 prepares students for more advanced calculus, whereas Math 115 delves more into probability and matrices for students in the biological and health sciences. Math 114 fulfills the formal reasoning requirement for the College. This course works with the textbook “Calculus” by Stewart.

Students found Professor Krieger to be accessible and “friendly during office hours” and “very enthusiastic” in the classroom. Although students appreciated his passion, many said Professor Krieger moved too quickly in lecture and would assume a familiarity with concepts students did not necessarily have. Students pointed out audibility issues, saying that he spoke too fast and softly. Others said he didn’t write clearly on the board, such that “taking notes in his class was always incredibly challenging.”

Some students wished the course were better organized and wanted more feedback in terms of grading.
